<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Uint8Array+to%5C%2Ffrom+base64+and+hex%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Uint8Array to/from base64 and hex</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Rezvan+Mahdavi+Hezaveh%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Rezvan Mahdavi Hezaveh</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250626" rel="nofollow">Thu, 26 Jun 2025 15:28:15 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emailsrez...@chromium.org, s...@chromium.org
ExplainerNone</pre><pre>
Specification<a rel="nofollow" href="https://tc39.es/proposal-arraybuffer-base64/spec">https://tc39.es/proposal-arraybuffer-base64/spec</a>
Summary
base64 is a common way to represent arbitrary binary data as ASCII. JavaScript has Uint8Arrays to work with binary data, but no built-in mechanism to encode that data as base64, nor to take base64'd data and produce a corresponding Uint8Arrays. This is a proposal to fix that. It also adds methods for converting between hex strings and Uint8Arrays.
Blink componentBlink>JavaScript>Language <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EJavaScript%3ELanguage%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EJavaScript%3ELanguage%22</a>>

LGTM2. Is there good documentation (e.g. in MDN) about which properties are inherited and from where? And how do CSS custom properties inherit in this parallel tree?
</pre><tt>Custom properties don't have any special treatment in this tree, so </tt><tt>:root, which is the originating element can specify the custom props </tt><tt>for this tree. I don't think there's currently good documentation. </tt><tt>CSSWG is still working to resolve on further properties to be </tt><tt>inherited through this (like timing function). When all of the obvious </tt><tt>items are resolved on, I can take on an action item to ensure </tt><tt>documentation is updated. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">

Summary
View Transitions project adds a tree of pseudo elements that have various animations applied to them. For ease of development and customization some niceties are provided, such as inheriting animation-duration. This feature adds another nicety: inherit animation-delay.
Blink component Blink>ViewTransitions
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EViewTransitions%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EViewTransitions%22</a>>
TAG review None
TAG review status Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
There's a small risk that developers rely on this properly not being inherited into the new/old pseudo elements from the group. However, it's unlikely since the animations are designed to work in unison. This is the reason for inheriting animation-duration, for example. This, and the fact that both Safari and Firefox are shipping this behavior makes me confident that the risk is minimal.

entry.title: RE: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Local Network Access
entry.summary: RE: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Local Network Access
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22RE%5C%3A+%5C%5BEXTERNAL%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Experiment%5C%3A+Local+Network+Access%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">RE: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Local Network Access</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22%27Erik+Anderson%27+via+blink%5C-dev%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">'Erik Anderson' via blink-dev</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250627" rel="nofollow">Fri, 27 Jun 2025 16:39:36 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Double checking: you will have the reverse OT infrastructure set up before proceeding to a stable channel experiment, correct?</pre><pre>
From: Rick Byers <rby...@chromium.org> Sent: Tuesday, June 24, 2025 1:40 PM To: Hubert Chao <hc...@chromium.org> Cc: blink-dev <blink-dev@chromium.org>; Chris Thompson <cth...@chromium.org>; chrome-secure-web-and-...@chromium.org; David Adrian <dadr...@google.com> Subject: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Local Network Access
LGTM to experiment via Finch in pre-stable channels.
I love the strategy of automatically popping a permission prompt. I'm optimistic we can get this tuned to minimize breakage while maximizing developer predictability and user understandability, but I can totally imagine that it'll take some tuning to get there. Please let us know when you feel confident enough in the data to start experimenting in stable - that'll be a key point in the rollout I believe and probably worthy of some extra discussion on the tradeoffs.
Ensuring users have transparency and control over local network access is important for security and privacy, thank you for working on it!
Rick
On Tue, Jun 24, 2025 at 4:21 PM Hubert Chao <hc...@chromium.org<<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:hc...@chromium.org">mailto:hc...@chromium.org</a>>> wrote: Note: this is for pre-stable experimentation through Finch, not for an Origin Trial.
Contact emails
cth...@chromium.org<<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:cth...@chromium.org">mailto:cth...@chromium.org</a>>
hc...@chromium.org<<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:hc...@chromium.org">mailto:hc...@chromium.org</a>>
Explainer
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/local-network-access">https://github.com/WICG/local-network-access</a>
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1n0kKxt9pS9qDlu_9i5W8IXA594r4pUOKmN9H35cZ8j0/edit?tab=t.0">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1n0kKxt9pS9qDlu_9i5W8IXA594r4pUOKmN9H35cZ8j0/edit?tab=t.0</a>
Design docs
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/local-network-access">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/local-network-access</a>
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1n0kKxt9pS9qDlu_9i5W8IXA594r4pUOKmN9H35cZ8j0/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1n0kKxt9pS9qDlu_9i5W8IXA594r4pUOKmN9H35cZ8j0/edit?usp=sharing</a>
Summary
Restricts the ability to make requests to the user's local network, gated behind a permission prompt.
A local network request is any request from a public website to a local IP address or loopback, or from a local website (e.g. intranet) to loopback. Gating the ability for websites to perform these requests behind a permission mitigates the risk of cross-site request forgery attacks against local network devices such as routers, and reduces the ability of sites to use these requests to fingerprint the user's local network.
This permission is restricted to secure contexts. If granted, the permissions additionally relaxes mixed content blocking for local network requests (since many local devices are not able to obtain publicly trusted TLS certificates for various reasons).
This work supersedes a prior effort called "Private Network Access" (e.g., <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5737414355058688">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5737414355058688</a>, <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5954091755241472">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5954091755241472</a>) which used preflight requests to have local devices opt-in.
Blink component
Blink>SecurityFeature>CORS>PrivateNetworkAccess<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ESecurityFeature%3ECORS%3EPrivateNetworkAccess%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ESecurityFeature%3ECORS%3EPrivateNetworkAccess%22</a>>
TAG review
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1116">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1116</a>
TAG review status
Pending
Origin Trial documentation link
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/local-network-access">https://github.com/WICG/local-network-access</a>
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
Interoperability risks:
LNA requires a Secure Context to make local network requests, but exempts some of these local network requests from mixed content checks (if the user grants permission). If another browser does not implement LNA, these same local network requests might be blocked as mixed content, or the site might need to serve over HTTPS for Chrome and over HTTP for browsers that don't implement LNA (to avoid triggering mixed content).
Compatibility risks:
There are some local network requests types that we cannot know ahead of time will be going to the local network (e.g., a subresource request to <a rel="nofollow" href="http://test.example">http://test.example</a><<a rel="nofollow" href="http://test.example/">http://test.example/</a>> which then resolves to 192.168.0.1). These would be blocked as mixed content, as mixed content checks happen before hostname resolution (i.e., they occur before "Obtain a connection" in Fetch). Explicit local IP addresses, `.local` domains, and fetch() requests with the new `targetAddressSpace` fetch() option are exempted from mixed content checks, but other connection types may be difficult for developers (e.g., WebSockets <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/local-network-access/issues/16">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/local-network-access/issues/16</a>).
We hope that our Dev Trial will help identify compatibility issues. When we fully ship we also plan on running a reverse origin trial to allow sites to (temporarily) opt-out of the secure contexts requirement -- this would be an escape hatch for mixed content.
Gecko: Under consideration (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/mozilla.org/g/dev-platform/c/B8oN3ARp_j0/m/rWKXmnj4AAAJ">https://groups.google.com/a/mozilla.org/g/dev-platform/c/B8oN3ARp_j0/m/rWKXmnj4AAAJ</a>) Firefox is prototyping based on our spec draft, no formal request for signals yet
WebKit: No signal No request for signals yet
Web developers: Mixed signals (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/local-network-access/issues">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/local-network-access/issues</a>) Feedback from developers has been mixed, both due the new burden of a permission prompt (compared to PNA) and from some of the difficulty of navigating mixed content (the same as PNA). Many developers understand the reasoning behind adding the new permission though, and are productively engaging on how they can avoid issues.
Other signals: Brave ships a "localhost access" permission (see <a rel="nofollow" href="https://brave.com/privacy-updates/27-localhost-permission/">https://brave.com/privacy-updates/27-localhost-permission/</a>)
Ergonomics
N/A
Activation
A new permission will be shown to users, which may be unexpected, and if users deny the permission functionality may break (potentially requiring additional support from site owners). Part of our goal for having a Dev Trial is to give site owners time to adjust their requests (especially if they need to use the mixed content exemptions) and to potentially adapt their UX flows so the permission requests are less surprising to users.
Security
Exempting some requests from mixed content checks based on declared targetAddressSpace could potentially be used to arbitrarily bypass mixed content. To avoid this, LNA does an additional check that the actual resolved address space matches what was declared, and blocks the request if it does not.
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Goals for experimentation
We intend to evaluate implementation of Local Network Access (LNA) through more widespread testing to ensure that we (a) do not capture any requests that are not LNA requests, and (b) all request that are LNA are captured and trigger a permissions check.
Intending to turn on up to 100% in Chrome Canary/Dev/Beta channel via Finch.
Experiment Risks
There may be false positives (request that are captured as LNA requests that are not) and false negatives (request that are LNA request that are not captured).
There is additional breakage risk with LNA request from non-secure contexts, as well as mixed-content LNA requests.
Ongoing technical constraints
None
Debuggability
When a request would be blocked under LNA, we add a new DevTools Issue with details.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
No
Android WebView currently doesn't support letting apps grant any new permission types, so the Local Network Access permission is currently unconditionally granted in WebView. Android is separately adding a Local Network permission which would apply to the app that embeds a WebView <a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.android.com/privacy-and-security/local-network-permission">https://developer.android.com/privacy-and-security/local-network-permission</a>
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?
No
We have started working on building out a test suite but it is still a work-in-progress. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/fetch/local-network-access">https://wpt.fyi/results/fetch/local-network-access</a>
DevTrial instructions
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/local-network-access">https://developer.chrome.com/blog/local-network-access</a>
Flag name on about://flags
local-network-access-check
Finch feature name
LocalNetworkAccessChecks
Requires code in //chrome?
True
Tracking bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/394009026">https://crbug.com/394009026</a>
Estimated milestones
DevTrial on desktop
138
DevTrial on Android
139

entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Extended lifetime shared workers
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Experiment%5C%3A+Extended+lifetime+shared+workers%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Extended lifetime shared workers</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250630" rel="nofollow">Mon, 30 Jun 2025 03:35:14 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails dome...@chromium.org, yyanagis...@chromium.org </pre><pre>
Explainer <a rel="nofollow" href="https://gist.github.com/domenic/c5bd38339f33b49120ae11b3b4af5b9b#file-1-explainer-md">https://gist.github.com/domenic/c5bd38339f33b49120ae11b3b4af5b9b#file-1-explainer-md</a>
Specification None
Summary
This adds a new option, `extendedLifetime: true`, to the `SharedWorker` constructor. This requests that the shared worker be kept alive even after all current clients have unloaded. The primary use case is to allow pages to perform asynchronous work that requires JavaScript after a page unloads, without needing to rely on a service worker.
Blink component Blink>Workers
TAG review <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1089">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1089</a>
TAG review status Pending
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
We intend to specify that the lifetime timeout for these shared workers be extended in the same way as service workers. Because the exact timeout of service workers is left implementation-defined, it's possible that code using this new feature could be non-interoperable. However, this has so far not proved to be a major problem in practice for service workers.
Gecko: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1227">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1227</a>) Some unofficial tentative positive signals and engagement in the proposal issue.
WebKit: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/492">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/492</a>) Some unofficial tentative negative signals in the proposal issue.
Web developers: Positive The problem of wanting to perform asynchronous work during unload is well-known, with the service worker workaround currently deployed, including by Google properties.
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Goals for experimentation
Ongoing technical constraints
None
Debuggability
No special support beyond DevTools' existing shared worker inspection support.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? No Shared workers are not yet supported on Android and Android WebView. However, we are concurrently working on enabling them there, and when we do, this feature will also be supported.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? Yes <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/workers/tentative/SharedWorker-extendedLifetime.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/workers/tentative/SharedWorker-extendedLifetime.html</a>
Flag name on about://flags None
Finch feature name SharedWorkerExtendedLifetime
Requires code in //chrome? False
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/400473072">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/400473072</a>
Estimated milestones
Origin trial desktop first 139
Origin trial desktop last 142
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (eg links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (eg, changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way). We are currently discussing some details in preparation for specification. The exact nature of how the lifetime extension works with regard to non-window clients, particularly, has only recently reached a tentative conclusion.

entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to prototype: HDR headroom for drawing to 2D canvas
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to prototype: HDR headroom for drawing to 2D canvas
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+prototype%5C%3A+HDR+headroom+for+drawing+to+2D+canvas%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to prototype: HDR headroom for drawing to 2D canvas</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22%27Christopher+Cameron%27+via+blink%5C-dev%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">'Christopher Cameron' via blink-dev</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250701" rel="nofollow">Tue, 01 Jul 2025 05:46:15 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Hello blink-dev!
After much churn, the industry has converged on a consistent and very-widely adopted way of handling HDR content, based on the concept of HDR headroom <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-color-hdr/#introducing-headroom">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-color-hdr/#introducing-headroom</a>>.</pre><pre>
A core feature unique to HDR is that HDR content can be drawn an infinite number of ways, often unrepresentable as a single bitmap (e.g, gainmap images). There exists a general problem wherein a HDR content must be put into pixels in a buffer. At that moment, this infinite number of ways of representing it must be collapsed into a single set of pixel values in a buffer.
This chrome feature is for the 2D canvas version <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/11165">https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/11165</a>> of the problem, but it may be helpful to peruse the related specifications of WebGPU texture upload <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/gpuweb/gpuweb/issues/5236">https://github.com/gpuweb/gpuweb/issues/5236</a>> and WebGL texture upload <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/KhronosGroup/WebGL/issues/3735">https://github.com/KhronosGroup/WebGL/issues/3735</a>>, since they are the same solution to the same problem (they are shipping as separate Chromium features, because their specs are separate and their development will be done in series).
Also of note is that a canvas can be a source of pixels (not just a destination) and there is a separate issue <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/11424">https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/11424</a>> (and a separate feature) for dealing with that side of things.
Contact emailsccame...@chromium.org
Explainer <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/ccameron-chromium/ColorWeb-CG/blob/master/canvas2d_hdr_headroom.md">https://github.com/ccameron-chromium/ColorWeb-CG/blob/master/canvas2d_hdr_headroom.md</a>
SpecificationNone
Summary
Adds a global HDR headroom attribute to CanvasRenderingContext2D. When drawing HDR content (e.g, gain map images), to the canvas' bitmap, this attribute will determine how much tone mapping should be performed (if any).
Blink componentBlink>Canvas <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECanvas%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECanvas%22</a>>
Search tagsHDR tone mapping canvas drawImage <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:HDR%20tone%20mapping%20canvas%20drawImage">https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:HDR%20tone%20mapping%20canvas%20drawImage</a>>
TAG reviewNone
TAG review statusPending
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
None. This is designed to provide an avenue through which interoperability for HDR content can be increased, while maintaining backwards compatibility with existing behavior (because SDR is forever).
*Gecko*: No signal
*WebKit*: No signal
*Web developers*: No signals
*Other signals*:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Goals for experimentation
Ongoing technical constraints
None
Debuggability
None
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>> ?No
Flag name on about://flagsNone
Finch feature nameCanvasGlobalHDRHeadroom
Requires code in //chrome?False
Tracking bug<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/428575083">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/428575083</a>
Estimated milestones
No milestones specified

entry.summary: Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to [Experiment] Origin Trial: Incoming Call Notifications
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5BEXTERNAL%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+%5C%5BExperiment%5C%5D+Origin+Trial%5C%3A+Incoming+Call+Notifications%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to [Experiment] Origin Trial: Incoming Call Notifications</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22%27Diego+Gonzalez%27+via+blink%5C-dev%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">'Diego Gonzalez' via blink-dev</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250701" rel="nofollow">Tue, 01 Jul 2025 06:12:47 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>
Hola Dominic,</pre><pre>
This was generated through a link to a doc<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1vlTlsQKThwaX0-lj_iZbVTzyqY7LioqERU8DK3u3XjI/edit?tab=t.0#bookmark=id.pygli2e122ic">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1vlTlsQKThwaX0-lj_iZbVTzyqY7LioqERU8DK3u3XjI/edit?tab=t.0#bookmark=id.pygli2e122ic</a>> in the process documentation<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.chromium.org/blink/launching-features/#origin-trials">https://www.chromium.org/blink/launching-features/#origin-trials</a>>. I would actually like to know how does one get to this link<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5110990717321216/gate/5269432429969408/intent">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5110990717321216/gate/5269432429969408/intent</a>> you have sent for a feature, as at least as a feature owner for Incoming Calls notifications chromestatus does not provide any indication on where to generate or find the current template for the blink-dev email to go to OT.
Could I be missing permissions to see this?
[cid:31807a01-7caf-4838-9bcc-eec5176d230e]
Regards,
Diego González (PWA PM @ Edge)
________________________________ From: Domenic Denicola <dome...@chromium.org> Sent: 01 July 2025 04:52 To: Diego Gonzalez <luigo...@microsoft.com> Cc: blink-dev <blink-dev@chromium.org>; Stanley Hon <sta...@microsoft.com>; Rob Paveza <rob.pav...@microsoft.com>; Limin Zhu (Edge) <li...@microsoft.com>; Ajay Rahatekar <ajayrahate...@google.com> Subject: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to [Experiment] Origin Trial: Incoming Call Notifications
You don't often get email from dome...@chromium.org. Learn why this is important<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification">https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification</a>> I'm curious how this email was generated. It doesn't follow the template created from ChromeStatus<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5110990717321216/gate/5269432429969408/intent">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5110990717321216/gate/5269432429969408/intent</a>>, and the non-standard subject line meant it wasn't picked up by the API owners review dashboard.
Anyway, this LGTM, and is approved to experiment from M139 to M141. However, please respond to the following, and correct the ChromeStatus entry as appropriate:
* The ChromeStatus entry says TAG review is not applicable. (The above email is missing this field.) Can you explain why that would be? * The ChromeStatus entry says there is no interop and compat risk. This seems unlikely, especially given that there are no signals from other vendors? * The ChromeStatus entry says there is no Finch flag. A Finch flag is required for all new features. Perhaps you confused Finch flag and Flag name on about://flags? * The ChromeStatus entry has no OT milestones, but this email has them. Please be sure to enter those into ChromeStatus so that it is properly tracked. * This email contains different answers for debuggability, platform support, and summary versus ChromeStatus. Please ensure these get harmonized.
On Tue, Jun 17, 2025 at 5:55 AM 'Diego Gonzalez' via blink-dev <blink-dev@chromium.org<<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:blink-dev@chromium.org">mailto:blink-dev@chromium.org</a>>> wrote: Spec The shape of the API and discussions are based on this explainer<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/MicrosoftEdge/MSEdgeExplainers/blob/main/Notifications/notifications_actions_customization.md">https://github.com/MicrosoftEdge/MSEdgeExplainers/blob/main/Notifications/notifications_actions_customization.md</a>>. Intended to live in the Notifications API<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://notifications.spec.whatwg.org/">https://notifications.spec.whatwg.org/</a>> spec.
Summary We would like to propose an extension to the Notifications API<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://notifications.spec.whatwg.org/">https://notifications.spec.whatwg.org/</a>> standard for incoming call scenarios to allow the notification action buttons to be customized and also allow the application to play a ringtone. This capability would make the incoming call notifications, which may require a faster immediate response, clearly distinguishable from the others to the user and would also contribute to increasing accessibility on the Web.

entry.title: [blink-dev] Clarification: Safe window.open with noopener, noreferrer and Parent Focus Capability
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Clarification: Safe window.open with noopener, noreferrer and Parent Focus Capability
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Clarification%5C%3A+Safe+window.open+with+noopener%2C+noreferrer+and+Parent+Focus+Capability%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Clarification: Safe window.open with noopener, noreferrer and Parent Focus Capability</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Kavan+Gondalia%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Kavan Gondalia</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250701" rel="nofollow">Tue, 01 Jul 2025 09:12:10 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>
Hi team,</pre><pre>
I'm working on a web application where I open a second tab using window.open() to host another part of my own app — for example, an excel sheet in a separate tab while keeping the main design interface open in the original one. Both tabs are from the same origin, but intentionally separated for UX and performance reasons.
To improve security and memory efficiency, I use noopener and noreferrer when opening the new tab. This helps avoid process and memory linkage between the tabs, especially with modern site isolation and performance models.
However, one critical interaction I’d like to preserve is the ability for the child tab to bring focus back to the original tab (its opener), for example after onClick button action. Without opener access, calling window.opener.focus() is no longer possible.
In short, I’m looking to achieve all three of the following:
-
Open a new tab for my own app using window.open() -
Use noopener and noreferrer for memory isolation -
Still allow the child tab to focus the parent tab
Right now, there doesn't seem to be a secure and reliable way to do this. I understand the restrictions exist for good reason, but it would be helpful.
This would help developers build secure multi-tab interfaces without compromising UX.
I’d appreciate any insights into whether this is already being discussed or considered as part of platform evolution.
Thanks for your time and for your work on web platform security and performance.
Best regards, Kavan Gondalia

entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Support+font%5C-feature%5C-settings+descriptor+in+%40font%5C-face+rule%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Support font-feature-settings descriptor in @font-face rule</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250702" rel="nofollow">Wed, 02 Jul 2025 19:53:56 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails sejalan...@microsoft.com </pre><pre>
Explainer None
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-fonts-4/#font-rend-desc">https://www.w3.org/TR/css-fonts-4/#font-rend-desc</a>
Summary
As CSS allows fine control over font features using 'font-feature-settings' at the element level, Chromium-based browsers currently lack support for these properties within '@font-face' declarations. This feature supports the string-based syntax for font-feature-settings as defined in CSS Fonts Level 4. Invalid or unrecognized feature tags will be ignored per specification. No binary or non-standard forms are supported. As OpenType fonts become more widely adopted, this enhancement will improve typographic control, reduce redundancy, and support a more scalable, modern approach to web design.
Blink component Blink>Fonts
TAG review None
TAG review status Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility

entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Secure+Payment+Confirmation%5C%3A+UX+Refresh%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Secure Payment Confirmation: UX Refresh</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250703" rel="nofollow">Thu, 03 Jul 2025 09:15:03 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails darwiny...@chromium.org, slobo...@chromium.org, smcgr...@chromium.org</pre><pre>
Explainer <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/197">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/197</a> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/275">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/275</a>
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://w3c.github.io/secure-payment-confirmation">https://w3c.github.io/secure-payment-confirmation</a>
Design docs
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/197">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/197</a> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/275">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/275</a> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/292">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/292</a> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/294">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/294</a> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/298">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/298</a>
Summary
Updates the UX elements for the SPC dialog on Android Chrome. Other than just UX presentation the following are being added: - Allowing merchants to provide an optional list of payment entity logos related to the payment that will be displayed in the UX (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/294">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/294</a>). - Returning different output states back to the merchant depending on whether the user wants to continue the transaction without SPC or to cancel the transaction (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/292">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/292</a>). Currently, we only send a single output state back for both cases. - A new payment detail label field will be added to the payment instrument so the text be presented across 2 lines in SPC (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/298">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/298</a>)
Blink component Blink>Payments
TAG review N/A (minor additive features)
TAG review status Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
Low risk. The SPC UX Refresh changes are only purely additive API shapes that are all backwards compatible. The risk is that other browser do not implement it.
Gecko: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/570">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/570</a>) Firefox has never finalized their view on SPC, so we updated the original SPC issue with a note on this additional capability.
WebKit: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/30">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/30</a>) Safari has never finalized their view on SPC, so we updated the original SPC issue with a note on this additional capability.
Web developers: Positive Responding to requests/feedback from web developers in the WPWG.
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Debuggability
Web developers should be able to try the new SPC UX Refresh through a Chrome flag, thus no changes are needed in devtools.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? No SPC UX Refresh is added to Secure Payment Confirmation which is supported only on Android, Windows, and Mac.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? No
DevTrial instructions <a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1w3RfvmoQqCvJkio4rxl0QR4BL1AzgHdv9a0qJhfCzpg">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1w3RfvmoQqCvJkio4rxl0QR4BL1AzgHdv9a0qJhfCzpg</a>
Flag name on about://flags enable-secure-payment-confirmation-ux-refresh
Finch feature name SecurePaymentConfirmationUxRefresh
Rollout plan Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome? False
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://g-issues.chromium.org/issues/405173922">https://g-issues.chromium.org/issues/405173922</a>
Launch bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4397413">https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4397413</a>
Measurement SPC UX Refresh is only additive to Secure Payment Confirmation: The Secure Payment Confirmation UseCounter will be used.
Availability expectation Secure Payment Confirmation is only in Chromium browsers for the foreseeable future.
Non-OSS dependencies
Does the feature depend on any code or APIs outside the Chromium open source repository and its open-source dependencies to function? None
Sample links
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://rsolomakhin.github.io/pr/spc-payment-entities-logos">https://rsolomakhin.github.io/pr/spc-payment-entities-logos</a> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://rsolomakhin.github.io/pr/spc-opt-out">https://rsolomakhin.github.io/pr/spc-opt-out</a>

entry.title: [blink-dev] Ready for Developer Testing: Partitioning :visited links history
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Ready for Developer Testing: Partitioning :visited links history
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Ready+for+Developer+Testing%5C%3A+Partitioning+%5C%3Avisited+links+history%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Ready for Developer Testing: Partitioning :visited links history</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Kyra+Seevers%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Kyra Seevers</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250115" rel="nofollow">Wed, 15 Jan 2025 11:56:20 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emailskyraseev...@chromium.org
Explainer<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/kyraseevers/Partitioning-visited-links-history">https://github.com/kyraseevers/Partitioning-visited-links-history</a></pre><pre>
Specification Issue<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/11151">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/11151</a>
Summary
To eliminate user browsing history leaks, anchor elements are styled as :visited if and only if they have been clicked from this top-level site and frame origin before. On the browser-side, this means that the VisitedLinks hashtable is now partitioned via "triple-keying", or by storing the following for each visited link: <link URL, top-level site, frame origin>. By only styling links that have been clicked on this site and frame before, the many side-channel attacks that have been developed to obtain :visited links styling information are now obsolete, as they no longer provide sites with new information about users.
Blink componentBlink>History>VisitedLinks <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EHistory%3EVisitedLinks%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EHistory%3EVisitedLinks%22</a>>
Search tagsvisited links <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:visited%20links">https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:visited%20links</a>>, :visited selector <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/features#tags::visited%20selector">https://chromestatus.com/features#tags::visited%20selector</a>>, partitioning history <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:partitioning%20history">https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:partitioning%20history</a>>
TAG review<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/896">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/896</a>
TAG review statusIssues addressed
Chromium Trial NameN/a
WebFeature UseCounter nameN/a
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
There has been lots of word-of-mouth interest from the Web Platform in adopting this feature cross-browser. We have interest from members of the CSSWG in specifying this solution in CSS Selectors, and we have a positive signal from Firefox that they are interested in implementing partitioning soon as well.
*Gecko*: Positive ( <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1040">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1040</a>)
*WebKit*: No signal ( <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/363">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/363</a>)
*Web developers*: No signals
*Other signals*: Positive initial signals from presentation at WebAppSec from both Apple and Firefox. At the XS Leaks Summit, Firefox stated exploration of :visited links partitioning in their privacy goals for the upcoming year at the XS-Leaks Summit. Positive or neutral initial signals from security and privacy researchers at the XS-Leaks summit. No security concerns about this design. Lots of interest in finally resolving this exploit. Feedback from UX that CSS extensibility is in-demand from developers right now, and this work would pave the way for less restricted CSS on anchor elements. In addition, support from various developers who believe that taking care of this long-standing privacy leak will allow their own security and privacy solutions to advance once history sniffing is no longer an issue.
Ergonomics
This design is asynchronous and not used in tandem with other APIs.
Activation
Since this is a Finch roll-out, there are no additional activation risks.
Security
For this design we worked with the Chrome Security Architecture team to ensure reasonable precautions were taken against leaks via renderer compromise.
WebView application risks
N/a this feature will not launch on WebView.
Goals for experimentation
The goal of this dev trial is to allow those interested to test out the partitioned :visited links model (with self links) by flipping a flag. This functionality is available beginning in Chrome Version 132.
Ongoing technical constraints
None
Debuggability
No DevTools support is required.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?No
This feature is not currently supported on iOS or Android Webview. For iOS, this feature requires WebKit to alter its CSS parsing to support triple-key partitioning. Android Webview relies on an entirely different system to populate history, so it will require a separate design.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>> ?No
This feature is not tested by Web Platform Tests because the :visited selector, in its current state, cannot be queried via JavaScript ( <a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Privacy_and_the_:visited_selector">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Privacy_and_the_:visited_selector</a>). As a result, we can only test :visited-ness via manual tests which rely on users visually confirming the correct links are :visited, or unit and integration tests internal to Chrome.
DevTrial instructions <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/Partitioning-visited-links-history?tab=readme-ov-file#how-to-experiment">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/Partitioning-visited-links-history?tab=readme-ov-file#how-to-experiment</a>
Flag name on about://flagsPartition the Visited Link Database, including 'self links'
Finch feature namePartitionVisitedLinkDatabaseWithSelfLinks
Requires code in //chrome?False
Tracking bug<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1448609">https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1448609</a>
Launch bug<a rel="nofollow" href="https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4330864">https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4330864</a>
Estimated milestones DevTrial on desktop 132 DevTrial on Android 132
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5101991698628608">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5101991698628608</a>
Links to previous Intent discussionsIntent to Prototype: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CA%2BmmbXbbLWwmRYH5SWx0%2BMWkfB2UY2miOAq4r0MZc34i_sWqBw%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CA%2BmmbXbbLWwmRYH5SWx0%2BMWkfB2UY2miOAq4r0MZc34i_sWqBw%40mail.gmail.com</a> Intent to Experiment: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CA%2BmmbXYy4CSMuPLY0HJuTbZt0qPz5ZUsGUToFJuCE%2BTfC86umA%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CA%2BmmbXYy4CSMuPLY0HJuTbZt0qPz5ZUsGUToFJuCE%2BTfC86umA%40mail.gmail.com</a> Intent to Experiment: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/U5AX0OXaxM8/m/tIGr4bJJBgAJ?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/U5AX0OXaxM8/m/tIGr4bJJBgAJ?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer</a>

<pre>Contact emails gast...@microsoft.com </pre><pre>

Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/pointerevents/pull/525/files">https://github.com/w3c/pointerevents/pull/525/files</a>
Summary
This feature introduces a standard that simplifies enabling or disabling handwriting input across multiple platforms. By specifying a new keyword in the touch-action CSS property, developers can now easily indicate whether an element or its subtree should allow handwriting input.
Blink component UI>Input>Text
Motivation
To disable handwriting input without this feature, developers would need to use preventDefault() on pen touch events, assuming that was an option for the user agent implementation of handwriting input. Android uses a non-standard `touch-action` configuration to disable handwriting input, this proposal will provide a standardized mechanism.
Initial public proposal <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/pointerevents/issues/516">https://github.com/w3c/pointerevents/issues/516</a>

entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: CSS text-box, text-box-trim and text-box-edge
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+CSS+text%5C-box%2C+text%5C-box%5C-trim+and+text%5C-box%5C-edge%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: CSS text-box, text-box-trim and text-box-edge</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Bramus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Bramus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250106" rel="nofollow">Mon, 06 Jan 2025 00:51:35 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre> On Friday, December 20, 2024 at 3:46:04 PM UTC+1 Mike Taylor wrote:
Thanks David for flagging.</pre><pre>
Can we hold off on shipping until the issue settles? On 12/19/24 10:44 AM, David Baron wrote:
I'm a little concerned that the discussion in <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/">https://github.com/w3c/</a> csswg-drafts/issues/10834 may lead to some changes; I think it's at least worth monitoring that issue over the next few weeks to see what happens there.
There’s also some ongoing discussion in <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/432#issuecomment-2553396257">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/432#issuecomment-2553396257</a>
about text-box.
-David
On Thu, Dec 19, 2024 at 4:38 AM Koji Ishii <ko...@chromium.org> wrote:
Thank you for checking this:
The spec you link has a red note saying:
"This is an early draft of a proposal, and might change significantly as design critiques and use cases are registered and various details and interactions with other properties are worked out. Do not ship (yet)."
Does that only apply to the properties you listed?
That's a left over, one removed as Mike pointed out but one still left. I'll check with the editor.
Coincidentally, Safari shipped these properties on Dec 11 <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/432#issuecomment-2537122575">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/432#issuecomment-2537122575</a>> .
2024年12月19日(木) 1:00 Daniel Bratell <bratel...@gmail.com>:
Ok, so let's go!
LGTM3
/Daniel On 2024-12-18 16:55, Mike Taylor wrote:
I had the same question (as it was noted in the WebKit position), but found <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/commit/3b15a485b2f9dfaa8e9ad3958ec262">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/commit/3b15a485b2f9dfaa8e9ad3958ec262</a> 5d7857f719. I assume this I2S means we agree. :) On 12/18/24 10:39 AM, Daniel Bratell wrote:
The spec you link has a red note saying:
"This is an early draft of a proposal, and might change significantly as design critiques and use cases are registered and various details and interactions with other properties are worked out. Do not ship (yet)."
Does that only apply to the properties you listed?
/Daniel On 2024-12-18 16:34, Yoav Weiss (@Shopify) wrote:
LGTM2
On Wednesday, December 18, 2024 at 4:29:51 PM UTC+1 Mike Taylor wrote:
LGTM1 On 12/11/24 11:49 AM, Koji Ishii wrote:
Contact emails lin...@chromium.org, ko...@chromium.org
Explainer None
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-inline-3/#text-edges">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-inline-3/#text-edges</a>
Summary
To achieve optical balance of text content, the text-box-trim and text-box-edge properties, along with the text-box shorthand property, make finer control of vertical alignment of text possible. The text-box-trim property specifies the sides to trim, above or below, and the text-box-edge property specifies how the edge should be trimmed. These properties allow developers to control vertical spacing precisely by using the font metrics. Note that the `ideographic` and `ideographic-ink`, two values for the text-box-edge property for CJK, are deferred to future releases due to open issues currently under discussion.
Blink component Blink>Layout>Inline <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ELayout%3EInline%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ELayout%3EInline%22</a>>
TAG review <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1021">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1021</a> TAG review status Pending
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
*Gecko*: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/</a> 1105)
*WebKit*: In development (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/">https://github.com/WebKit/</a> standards-positions/issues/432) Available under a flag, original bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=245599">https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=245599</a>
*Web developers*: Positive (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://medium.com/microsoft-">https://medium.com/microsoft-</a> design/leading-trim-the-future-of-digital-typesetting-d082d84b202) <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/markdalgleish/figma-leading-trim">https://github.com/markdalgleish/figma-leading-trim</a>
*Other signals*:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
No.
Debuggability
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>> ? Yes
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-inline/text-box-trim">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-inline/text-box-trim</a>? label=experimental&label=master&aligned
Flag name on about://flags text-box-trim
Finch feature name CSSTextBoxTrim
Requires code in //chrome? False
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1411581">https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1411581</a>
Estimated milestones Shipping on desktop 133 DevTrial on desktop 128 Shipping on Android 133 DevTrial on Android 128 Shipping on WebView 133
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way). None.
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/">https://chromestatus.com/</a> feature/5174589850648576?gate=5185376392577024
Links to previous Intent discussions Intent to Prototype: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups">https://groups</a>. google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/Sn8TF5KHrRU

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Extend Experiment: Storage Access Headers
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Extend Experiment: Storage Access Headers
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Extend+Experiment%5C%3A+Storage+Access+Headers%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Extend Experiment: Storage Access Headers</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20241217" rel="nofollow">Tue, 17 Dec 2024 12:36:48 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<tt>Thanks Chris and Sam. The spec work and tests demonstrated sufficient </tt><tt>progress to extend </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>LGTM to extend to 135 inclusive (I guess it's a retroactive approval to </tt><tt>get 6 milestones instead of the 2 you originally requested). </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre>
On 12/17/24 2:52 PM, Chris Fredrickson wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>Following up on this - we'd like to amend this I2EE to request an </tt><tt>extension for another *3* milestones, to M135, to give ourselves more </tt><tt>buffer to resolve any issues. (We understand that a feature may run an </tt><tt>origin trial for up to 6 milestones. The first release with this OT </tt><tt>was M130.) </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>We still see shipping in M133 as a possibility, provided that we </tt><tt>resolve Mozilla's outstanding concern quickly. We're working to do so </tt><tt>and plan to send an I2S for review once it is resolved. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
On Wednesday, December 11, 2024 at 3:51:17 PM UTC-5 Sam LeDoux wrote:
Alex,
Thank you for the context, and that caveat sounds fair. To answer your question, we have not seen much traffic under the current OT.
Best, Sam LeDoux
On Wed, Dec 11, 2024 at 11:33 AM Alex Russell <slightly...@chromium.org> wrote:
Hey Sam,
Thanks for the updates.
We discussed this at this morning's API OWNERS meeting, and given that there's some renaming risk, it sounds like there's support to extend you past the 1 extra milestone you're asking for under the caveat that breaking changes (e.g., a renaming) be implemented ASAP. Is there much traffic under the current OT?
Best,
Alex
On Wednesday, December 11, 2024 at 5:06:24 AM UTC-8 Sam LeDoux wrote:
Mike,
Thank you for the response. To address your comments:
This is trending positive, but
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1084#issuecomment-2471319900">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1084#issuecomment-2471319900</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1084#issuecomment-2471319900">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1084#issuecomment-2471319900</a>> some possible renaming. Can we try to sort that out with Mozilla before shipping?
Thank you for pointing this out, we will discuss the naming with Mozilla again.
What feedback have you received so far from participants?
One piece of feedback we received was that the SAH retry behavior with cross-site redirects was unintuitive, which led us to create this issue <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/privacycg/storage-access/issues/210">https://github.com/privacycg/storage-access/issues/210</a>>, and update the behavior in chromium <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6020980">https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6020980</a>> accordingly.
This rationale sounds like using the OT as a soft-launch, which isn't great. Do you think your partners will learn something in the requested extra 4 weeks such that you might meaningfully incorporate the feedback ahead of a launch? (I think the answer is probably no, but I'd love to hear your perspective).
One of our main motivators for extending the origin trial was feedback from a partner that they have not had a chance to begin experimenting and would appreciate having an additional milestone to do so. An extra 4 weeks may not be much time, but having any additional feedback from this partner experimenting would be helpful ahead of the launch.
Can you also comment on substantial progress for the following (as relevant), since the original OT?
* Draft spec (early draft is ok, but must be spec-like and associated with the appropriate standardization venue, or WICG)
We have published a spec since the original OT, here <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacycg.github.io/storage-access-headers/">https://privacycg.github.io/storage-access-headers/</a>>. A link can also be found in the platform status entry.
* WPT tests
We have written a suite of WPTs for Storage Access Headers that were recently merged into the wpt repo <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/pull/49502">https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/pull/49502</a>>.
Best, Sam LeDoux
On Tue, Dec 10, 2024, 8:14 AM Mike Taylor <miketa...@chromium.org> wrote:
On 12/9/24 3:39 PM, 'Sam LeDoux' via blink-dev wrote:
</pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Contact emails
sled...@google.com <<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:sled...@google.com">mailto:sled...@google.com</a>>, johann...@chromium.org <<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:johann...@chromium.org">mailto:johann...@chromium.org</a>>, cfred...@chromium.org <<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:cfred...@chromium.org">mailto:cfred...@chromium.org</a>>
Explainer
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/privacycg/storage-access-headers">https://github.com/privacycg/storage-access-headers</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/privacycg/storage-access-headers">https://github.com/privacycg/storage-access-headers</a>>
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacycg.github.io/storage-access-headers">https://privacycg.github.io/storage-access-headers</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://privacycg.github.io/storage-access-headers">https://privacycg.github.io/storage-access-headers</a>>
Summary
Storage Access Headers offer an alternate way for authenticated embeds to opt in for unpartitioned cookies. These headers indicate whether embedded resources would like to load with permission they have already been granted, reducing loads and latency overall for these use cases.
Blink component
Blink>StorageAccessAPI
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Blink%3EStorageAccessAPI">https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Blink%3EStorageAccessAPI</a>>
Search tags
storage access api <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:storage%20access%20api">https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:storage%20access%20api</a>>, storage access headers
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:storage%20access%20headers">https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:storage%20access%20headers</a>>
TAG review
Not needed, per <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/982">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/982</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/982">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/982</a>>.
TAG review status
Not applicable
</pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;"> (This should probably be changed to Resolution: satisfied, per the above link) </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Origin Trial Name
Storage Access Headers
Chromium Trial Name
StorageAccessHeader
Origin Trial documentation link
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/cfredric/storage-access-headers">https://github.com/cfredric/storage-access-headers</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/cfredric/storage-access-headers">https://github.com/cfredric/storage-access-headers</a>>
WebFeature UseCounter name
kStorageAccessAPI_requestStorageAccess_Method
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
This feature poses minor compatibility risk, since the Origin header is now included on requests that include the "Sec-Fetch-Storage-Access: inactive" header - and some servers do not yet properly handle the Origin header. However, this risk is low, because:
* The "inactive" header is only included on clients that already block third-party cookies.
* The presence of the "inactive" header implies that the request is cross-site, and that the site in question already uses the Storage Access API (which is relatively new to the web platform) or that the context is an "A > B > A" embedding scenario (which are not expected to be common).
* This feature omits the Origin header from requests whose `credentials` mode is not "include".
Gecko: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1084">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1084</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1084">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1084</a>>)
</pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;"> This is trending positive, but
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1084#issuecomment-2471319900">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1084#issuecomment-2471319900</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1084#issuecomment-2471319900">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1084#issuecomment-2471319900</a>> some possible renaming. Can we try to sort that out with Mozilla before shipping? </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
WebKit: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/412">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/412</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/412">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/412</a>>)
Web developers: Positive (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/privacycg/storage-access/issues/130">https://github.com/privacycg/storage-access/issues/130</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/privacycg/storage-access/issues/130">https://github.com/privacycg/storage-access/issues/130</a>>) Other feature requests: * <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/privacycg/storage-access/issues/170">https://github.com/privacycg/storage-access/issues/170</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/privacycg/storage-access/issues/170">https://github.com/privacycg/storage-access/issues/170</a>>* <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/privacycg/storage-access/issues/189">https://github.com/privacycg/storage-access/issues/189</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/privacycg/storage-access/issues/189">https://github.com/privacycg/storage-access/issues/189</a>>
Other signals:
WebView application risks
None
Goals for experimentation
This experiment would allow us to receive and incorporate feedback on the browser's application of the `Sec-Fetch-Storage-Access` request header, as well as the browser's handling of the `Activate-Storage-Access` header before the feature is fully launched.
</pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;"> What feedback have you received so far from participants? </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Reason this experiment is being extended
We are currently targeting M133 for the stable launch of Storage Access Headers; therefore, we would like to extend the Origin Trial to last through M132, as partners have expressed a desire to continue experimenting with the Storage Access Headers feature up until it begins launching to stable.
</pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;"> This rationale sounds like using the OT as a soft-launch, which isn't great. Do you think your partners will learn something in the requested extra 4 weeks such that you might meaningfully incorporate the feedback ahead of a launch? (I think the answer is probably no, but I'd love to hear your perspective).
Can you also comment on substantial progress for the following (as relevant), since the original OT?
* Draft spec (early draft is ok, but must be spec-like and associated with the appropriate standardization venue, or WICG) * TAG review (see exceptions) * bit.ly/blink-signals <<a rel="nofollow" href="http://bit.ly/blink-signals">http://bit.ly/blink-signals</a>> requests * Outreach for feedback from the spec community * WPT tests
</pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Ongoing technical constraints
None
Debuggability
Currently best debugged via chrome://net-export logs, as Chrome DevTools does not show the full chain of network events. We may add improved debugging capabilities in the future.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
No.
Supported for Mac, Windows, Linux, Chrome OS, and Android.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?
Yes
Flag name on chrome://flags
#storage-access-headers
Requires code in //chrome?

entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Protected Audience (B&A) - Private Aggregation & downsampling forDebuggingOnly reporting
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Protected Audience (B&A) - Private Aggregation & downsampling forDebuggingOnly reporting
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Protected+Audience+%5C%28B%5C%26A%5C%29+%5C-+Private+Aggregation+%5C%26+downsampling+forDebuggingOnly+reporting%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Protected Audience (B&A) - Private Aggregation & downsampling forDebuggingOnly reporting</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Paul+Jensen%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Paul Jensen</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20241217" rel="nofollow">Tue, 17 Dec 2024 12:45:17 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails
pauljen...@chromium.org</pre><pre>
qingxi...@google.com
Explainer
For original Protected Audience Private Aggregation reporting support: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/pull/386">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/pull/386</a>
For original Protected Audience downsampling forDebuggingOnly reporting: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/pull/1020">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/pull/1020</a>
Specification
Private aggregation reporting:
-
Web spec: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/pull/1344">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/pull/1344</a> -
Protocol spec:
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/privacysandbox/draft-ietf-bidding-and-auction-services/pull/15">https://github.com/privacysandbox/draft-ietf-bidding-and-auction-services/pull/15</a>
Downsampling fDO:
-
Web spec: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/pull/1325">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/pull/1325</a> -
Protocol spec:
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/privacysandbox/draft-ietf-bidding-and-auction-services/pull/17">https://github.com/privacysandbox/draft-ietf-bidding-and-auction-services/pull/17</a>
Summary
This feature adds changes necessary in Chrome to support two reporting mechanisms for Protected Audience (PA) auctions run on Bidding and Auction Services (B&A) <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/privacysandbox/protected-auction-services-docs/blob/main/bidding_auction_services_api.md">https://github.com/privacysandbox/protected-auction-services-docs/blob/main/bidding_auction_services_api.md</a>> :
1.
Private Aggregation Reporting: for measuring aggregate, cross-site data in a privacy preserving manner. 2.
Downsampling of forDebuggingOnly (fDO) reports: changes necessary in the client to support the eventual implementation of downsampling of fDO in B&A. Chrome previously supported these reporting mechanisms for on-device PA auctions, and this feature brings them to B&A on-server auctions.
Blink component
Blink>InterestGroups <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Blink%3EInterestGroups">https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list?q=component:Blink%3EInterestGroups</a>>
TAG review
For Protected Audience: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/723">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/723</a>
For Protected Audience Bidding and Auction Services: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1009">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1009</a>
TAG review status
Completed for Protected Audience, resolved unsatisfied.
RisksInteroperability and Compatibility
Feature represents optional new behavior that shouldn’t break existing usage.
Gecko & WebKit: For Protected Audiences in general - Negative from Mozilla <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/770#issuecomment-2432124085">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/770#issuecomment-2432124085</a>>. No signal from Webkit <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/158#issuecomment-2432121278">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/158#issuecomment-2432121278</a>> .
Edge: Edge is running an Origin Trial of the Ad Selection API <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/privacy-preserving-ads/blob/main/README.md">https://github.com/WICG/privacy-preserving-ads/blob/main/README.md</a>> which shares a Web API and services protocol with PA. Their auction reporting doc <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/privacy-preserving-ads/blob/main/Auction%20Reporting.md">https://github.com/WICG/privacy-preserving-ads/blob/main/Auction%20Reporting.md</a>> says future work includes aggregate reporting which can be facilitated by this.
Web developers:
Private aggregation reporting in Protected Audience: Discussed on github (1 <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/issues/164">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/issues/164</a>>, 2 <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/issues/16">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/issues/16</a>>, 3 <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/issues/54">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/issues/54</a>>, 4 <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/issues/289">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/issues/289</a>>, 5 <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/patcg-individual-drafts/private-aggregation-api/issues/12">https://github.com/patcg-individual-drafts/private-aggregation-api/issues/12</a>> ).
Downsampled forDebuggingOnly in Protected Audience: Discussed here <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/issues/632">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/issues/632</a>> and in person here <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/blob/main/meetings/2024-01-17-FLEDGE-call-minutes.md#:~:text=on%20the%20URL.-,forDebuggingOnly%20availability,-%2D%20%23632">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/blob/main/meetings/2024-01-17-FLEDGE-call-minutes.md#:~:text=on%20the%20URL.-,forDebuggingOnly%20availability,-%2D%20%23632</a>> .
Debuggability
On-device API surfaces should be debuggable in Chrome DevTools, and we’ve added extensive mechanisms for debugging <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/privacysandbox/fledge-docs/blob/main/debugging_protected_audience_api_services.md">https://github.com/privacysandbox/fledge-docs/blob/main/debugging_protected_audience_api_services.md</a>> Bidding and Auction services <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/privacysandbox/protected-auction-services-docs/blob/main/bidding_auction_services_api.md#related-documents">https://github.com/privacysandbox/protected-auction-services-docs/blob/main/bidding_auction_services_api.md#related-documents</a>> .
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
It will be supported on all platforms that support Protected Audience, so all but WebView.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>> ?
We plan to add WPTs to cover this API shortly. We already have WPTs for Protected Audience Bidding and Auction Services and for Protected Audience private aggregation reporting, and will extend these accordingly.
Flag name on chrome://flags
None
Finch feature name
EnableBandAPrivateAggregation,
EnableBandASampleDebugReports
Requires code in //chrome?
False
Estimated milestones
Shipping on desktop and Android in M132.
Anticipated spec changes
None

Summary
Add MediaStreamTrack support to the Web Speech API. The Web Speech API is a web standard API that allows developers to incorporate speech recognition and synthesis into their web pages. Currently, the Web Speech API uses the user's default microphone as the audio input. MediaStreamTrack support allows websites to use the Web Speech API to caption other sources of audio including remote audio tracks.
